[i]Lost Judgment[/i] takes everything that made Judgment unforgettable ‚Äî the legal mystery, the emotional character drama, the exhilarating martial arts combat, and the densely detailed streets of Japan ‚Äî and elevates it to a whole new level. It is one of RGG Studio‚Äôs most ambitious and thematically powerful games, unafraid to dive into dark, uncomfortable topics while still delivering the humor, heart, and chaos fans expect.

Takayuki Yagami returns stronger, wiser, and more determined. What begins as a seemingly simple investigation rapidly expands into a sprawling conspiracy involving bullying, suicide, corruption, revenge, and systemic failure. The narrative is fearless in its approach ‚Äî it explores how institutions can fail victims, how trauma shapes people, and how the pursuit of justice can become dangerous when morality is blurred. Every chapter raises the stakes, and the emotional weight of the story builds steadily until it becomes gut-wrenching.

The cast is phenomenal. Yagami continues to be one of gaming‚Äôs most human and layered protagonists, and Kaito once again brings warmth, loyalty, and emotional grounding. New characters ‚Äî from the dangerous but charismatic antagonists to the students Yagami works with ‚Äî are exceptionally written. The dynamic between characters drives the story, and every major reveal feels impactful, earned, and unforgettable.

Combat has reached its peak here. Yagami now has multiple martial arts styles ‚Äî Crane, Tiger, and the new Snake style ‚Äî each designed for different tactical approaches. Crane excels in crowd control with acrobatic spins and sweeping kicks, Tiger delivers raw power to break defenses, and Snake enables counters and takedowns that turn an opponent‚Äôs aggression against them. Fights are fast, stylish, heavy-hitting, and visually spectacular. New mobility options and parkour mechanics make confrontations feel more fluid and cinematic than ever.

The investigation gameplay has evolved dramatically. Stealth segments are improved, tailing is more strategic, and evidence gathering is more engaging. Chase scenes are high-energy, puzzle solving adds thoughtful variety, and the game ensures that being a detective never feels repetitive. Every tool Yagami uses ‚Äî from gadgets to observation skills ‚Äî reinforces immersion rather than distraction.

Where [i]Lost Judgment[/i] truly leaps beyond its predecessor is in its world and side activities. The high-school setting is one of the game‚Äôs most brilliant ideas, introducing ‚ÄúSchool Stories,‚Äù a huge interconnected set of subplots that range from deeply emotional to completely insane. Street dancing competitions, boxing leagues, robotics clubs, biker gangs, photography clubs ‚Äî each built with surprising depth, storytelling, and character development. What begins as a case turns into a true connection between Yagami and the students, giving the game heart and humanity that lingers long after you finish.

And, of course, Kamurocho and Ijincho are overflowing with RGG Studio personality: arcades, Virtual Fighter, Drone League, skateboards, gambling, bar interactions, girlfriend routes, challenging mini-stories, and dozens of side cases filled with absurd humor and emotional resonance. It‚Äôs impossible to walk ten steps without stumbling into something entertaining.

Visually and cinematically, [i]Lost Judgment[/i] is stunning. The Dragon Engine delivers lifelike animation, incredible facial detail, realistic lighting, and dramatic camera direction. The soundtrack perfectly captures the emotional extremes ‚Äî brooding detective themes, tense investigation tracks, comedic melodies for lighter moments, and high-octane battle music with heavy bass and electric guitars that make every fight feel legendary.

[i]Lost Judgment[/i] is a masterpiece of investigative storytelling ‚Äî darker, bigger, and more polished than ever without losing the soul of the franchise. It challenges players emotionally and morally while delivering constant excitement, humor, and heart.

It isn‚Äôt just about solving a case ‚Äî it‚Äôs about fighting for justice in a world that looks away.

And Takayuki Yagami refuses to look away.

A sequel to Judgment, we play as Detective Yagami. While it takes place in the same setting as the Yakuza games, we are shown the point-of-view of someone from outside the organization. Here, we see how the Yakuza‚Äôs decisions impact those of regular civillians. Thankfully, we control someone that is skilled in the martial arts and can go toe-to-toe with even the toughest criminals.

This time, we are tasked in solving a high profile case linked to childhood bullying. This topic is very realistic and adds nuance to the characters and their motivations. Is everything that is legal, morally correct? Is all of vigilantism bad? What are the limits of the law and those acting against it? It tackles topics that even until now are up for debate.

In terms of gameplay, it‚Äôs the same fare as the other RGG Studios games, and it uses the Dragon Engine as well. Yagami now has four fighting styles, Crane, Tiger, Boxer, and Snake. These are fun to use and each has a variety of unique quirks. My favorite is the Tiger style just because of Flux Fissure that I‚Äôve been spamming since the first game. Combat is smoother this time around, probably the second best in the series next to the newer Gaiden.

Min-games are plentiful and I spent most of my time in the Robotics Club challenges. I loved this simple capture the flag game so much. Unlocking upgrades to the robot is fun and I steamrolled this entire substory at once.

I also enjoyed the boxing, dancing, and motorcycle racing mini-games. There is so much to do here, from dating the school nurse to shredding the streets with your skateboard. I also completed the Kaito Files Expansion, which added even more hours into the game and let us play as the supporting character, Kaito.

Just like other games from RGG Studios, it combines lighthearted humor with sudden flashes of seriousness and maturity. If this is something you‚Äôre interested in, or just want more from the RGG world, this game is for you.
